“返本开新”的古老智慧对于当前的世界显得尤为重要，因此对“古典学”的呼唤近年来不绝于耳，在青年学生中产生了一定的影响。只是对于何谓“回归”、何谓“古典学”这样的问题，认真的学理探讨却十分欠缺。面向青年的呼唤如果没有严格的学理作为基础，在青年学生中必将造成不应有的混乱。基于任课教师作为历史学者对相关问题的思考和研究，本课程希望通过对世界各个古典文化的史学考察，帮助青年学生反思“回归”浪潮、重新理解“古典学”和“古典”概念，开拓文化眼界、深化对世界的过去和未来的思考。在知识上介绍世界主要古典文化的出现和影响的同时，启发学生们合理地认识古典时代的重要性，并在此基础上对世界文明的过去和未来具有理性的独立思考能力。

我们将“古典时代”定义为一种文明在滥觞时期所经历的从小国到大国，从分裂到统一的历史时期，这一时期所形成的文化价值和社会治理模式以传统的形式对该文明后世的发展产生持久而深刻的影响。对于欧洲文明而言，希腊罗马时代是他们的古典时代；对于东亚文明来说，春秋秦汉是古典时代；对于更为古老的两河流域来说，早王朝到阿卡德时期是其古典时代；对于犹太文明来说，所谓大流散之前的时代被理解为古典时代；对于印度文明来说，后吠陀时代到阿育王时代可以认为是其古典时代。这些以文明为单位人为分别出来的各个古典时代的集合，则可以认为是当前世界文明的古典时代，因为当前的世界文明依然受到它们的作用和影响。本课程介绍各古典时代的文化价值和制度发明，讨论它们绵延至今的影响及其理由。

This course examines how people around the world understand kinship by birth, family membership, marriage, and descent from a common ancestor and how these ideas affect social identities and personal relationships.  Course readings begin with a survey of the classic anthropological findings about kin relationships and with studying the standard techniques that anthropologists have developed for modeling/diagramming genealogical relationships.  Topics to be discussed include the impact of gender on personal relationships, how parent-child relationships are construed through concepts of nature and nurture, the impact of globalization on the creation and maintenance of kin ties, and how the increasing individualization of modern life affects marriage, relationships within families, and wider kin networks.

Art and Literature in Renaissance Florence
Art and Literature in Renaissance Florence
历史文化学院（旅游学院）

The course would tackle a most stimulating and rich topic: the complex interplay between art and literature in Renaissance Florence, from the founding father of Italian humanism (Francis Petrarch) to the famous collection of lives of artists put together by Giorgio Vasari. By covering these two crucial centuries (1350-1550) in the shaping of Western culture the course would cover a wealth of highly influential and well-known texts and artworks. Students will be introduced to writings by Petrarch, Boccaccio, Bruni, Alberti, Poliziano, Ficino, Machiavelli and Vasari (just to name some famous authors). Likewise, they will be shown masterpieces by artists such as Giotto, Masaccio, Brunelleschi, Botticelli, Ghirlandaio, Leonardo and Michelangelo, as many of the texts in this course comment on their works. Finally, propaganda and city image will play a crucial role, since most works of art to be discussed had significant political connotations.

For decades archaeologists have been trying to develop methodologies that will help them determine what activities took place in and around domestic structures. Since people tend to clean activity areas,especially those that are used repeatedly, visible artifacts like  pottery, bones and stone tools are rarely discovered in the context where they were originally used. Instead, such artifacts are usually discovered in refuse heaps or other secondary contexts. Recently however, a group of young scholars working in the Near East have been developing new analytical methods to tackle this problem.

In this course, we engage with works by diverse authors including missionaries, soldiers, religious pilgrims, scientists, mountaineers, and anthropologists who have explored Tibet since the 18th century. We begin with an overview of colonialism and Orientalism as a necessary context for understanding the West’s encounters with Tibet. We then examine the “Great Game” – the contest between the British and Russian empires for supremacy in Central Asia during the 19th century. The modern period ushered in mountaineering and tourism, which became an important vehicles for cross-cultural encounters. Finally, we examine some attempts by people in the Tibet to define their own identities amidst accelerating globalization and the integration of their communities into China.

2、开拓视野，放眼亚洲，对佛教遗存的类型、亚洲各地区的重要佛教遗迹有一定了解；

More than a thousand years before the Bible the world’s earliest literature was written in the cuneiform script of the Ancient Near East on clay tablets in Ancient Mesopotamia (today’s Iraq). This course provides an opportunity to read the great literary works of Mesopotamian Civilization including The Sumerian Flood Story, The Gilgamesh Epic, Enuma Elish (the Babylonian Creation Myth), and Wisdom texts such as Ludlul-Bel-Nemeqi (the Babylonian Job) against the background of the philosophy, history, science, and culture of Ancient Near Eastern civilization. Students will read the ancient sources in translation, and participate in a program of lectures and activities, which will restore the myths, epics, and narratives to be studied to their original historical and cultural context, while also examining the relevance of these works in our world of the 21st century.

The course will consist of 16 hours of lectures covering the Bronze Age archaeology of Europe, but also considering aspects of the period in Eurasia more generally. The course will focus on field monuments but also on themes that have been of particular importance in European archaeology in recent years. Particular topics to be covered include settlement, burial, agriculture, mining and metallurgy, trade and interaction, ritual aspects including hoarding, transport technology, warfare, and social structure. In addition I will cover the general position and knowledge of ancient salt production, especially that in the Bronze Age, along with a presentation of recent work in Europe on novel technologies used for the mass production of this indispensable mineral.
